Posts.Content: momof4va wrote: About 18 months ago I had an abnormal mammogram, followed by needle biopsy and excisional biopsy. Subsequent 6 month and 12 month mammograms were normal. Now experiencing shortness of breath for almost 2 weeks, which I have seen my PC provider for. D-dimer lab result is slightly elevated but CT and PE Study of lungs is normal. BNP, PFT, EKG all normal. Is there anything I should be concerned about from a Breast Health perspective? Last screening mammogram was in July and was normal. momof4va Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Shortness of Breath - Should I be concerned? momof4va hugz4u

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2016 06:42PM momof4va wrote: Thanks panthrah. After two needle biopsies and one surgical biopsy all results are benign although my BS has recommended I see a MO to discuss whether or not medication is necessary since my body is producing atypical cells. Not sure I feel about medication. How do they determine who should take meds?
Posts.Title: So Far Benign, but still have more testing to go. momof4va Sweet_Pea

Posts.Content: momof4va wrote: Since early June I have had the following (all in the right breast): 1. diagnostic mammogram - Dx micro-calcifications BI RADS 4; and ultrasound - Dx negative. 2. a stereotactic biopsy - Dx Flat Epithelial Atypia w/ calcifications, stromal sclerosis; 3. a breast MRI - Dx mildly suspicious focal area non-mass enhancement 1.3cm x 1.0cm BI RADS 4 (different from the FEA found on #2). I now need a MRI guided biopsy to check out #2 before I have an excisional biopsy to check out #1. To me,  this seems like a lot of testing for benign atypical cells. Anyone else have this many steps before a final diagnosis? Is this normal? momof4va Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: So Far Benign, but still have more testing to go. momof4va Sweet_Pea

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2016 12:06PM momof4va wrote: Thanks kwhit. I see the MO on Tuesday. In the meantime, I also posted on JH Ask an Expert. Here is their response: so no cancer. good news. if you have additional risk factors, like family history, then the MO will discuss tamoxifen perhaps. ADH is a marker for risk. taking it all out doesn't make that risk go away.
